messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 59 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Computing the Largest Bond and the Maximum Connected Cut of a Graph This work is partially supported by JST CREST JPMJCR1401, and JSPS KAKENHI grant numbers JP17H01788, JP16K16010, JP17K19960, and JP19K21537, and by São Paulo Research Foundation (FAPESP) grant number 2015/11937-9, and Rio de Janeiro Research Foundation (FAPERJ) grant number E-26/203.272/2017, and by National Council for Scientific and Technological Development (CNPq-Brazil) grant numbers 308689/2017-8, 425340/2016-3, 313026/2017-3, 422829/2018-8, 303726/2017-2. The Japanese authors thank Akitoshi Kawamura and Yukiko Yamauchi for giving an opportunity to discuss in the Open Problem Seminar in Kyushu University, Japan. Preliminary versions of this paper appeared in [27] and [22].

Paper Abstract: Abstract The cut-set ∂(S)𝑆\partial(S) of a graph G=(V,E)𝐺𝑉𝐸G=(V,E) is the set of edges that have one endpoint in S⊂V𝑆𝑉S\subset V and the other endpoint in V∖S𝑉𝑆V\setminus S, and whenever G​[S]𝐺delimited-[]𝑆G[S] is connected, the cut [S,V∖S]𝑆𝑉𝑆[S,V\setminus S] of G𝐺G is called a connected cut. A bond of a graph G𝐺G is an inclusion-wise minimal disconnecting set of G𝐺G, i.e., bonds are cut-sets that determine cuts [S,V∖S]𝑆𝑉𝑆[S,V\setminus S] of G𝐺G such that G​[S]𝐺delimited-[]𝑆G[S] and G​[V∖S]𝐺delimited-[]𝑉𝑆G[V\setminus S] are both connected. Contrasting with a large number of studies related to maximum cuts, there exist very few results regarding the largest bond of general graphs. In this paper, we aim to reduce this gap on the complexity of computing the largest bond, and the maximum connected cut of a graph. Although cuts and bonds are similar, we remark that computing the largest bond and the maximum connected cut of a graph tends to be harder than computing its maximum cut. We show that it does not exist a constant-factor approximation algorithm to compute the largest bond, unless P=NPPNP\mbox{P}=\mbox{NP}. Also, we show that Largest Bond and Maximum Connected Cut are NP-hard even for planar bipartite graphs, whereas Maximum Cut is trivial on bipartite graphs and polynomial-time solvable on planar graphs. In addition, we show that Largest Bond and Maximum Connected Cut are NP-hard on split graphs, and restricted to graphs of clique-width w𝑤w they can not be solved in time f​(w)×no​(w)𝑓𝑤superscript𝑛𝑜𝑤f(w)\times n^{o(w)} unless the Exponential Time Hypothesis fails, but they can be solved in time f​(w)×nO​(w)𝑓𝑤superscript𝑛𝑂𝑤f(w)\times n^{O(w)}. Finally, we show that both problems are fixed-parameter tractable when parameterized by the size of the solution, the treewidth, and the twin-cover number. Keywords— bond; cut; maximum cut; connected cut; FPT; treewidth; clique-width.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 59 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 59"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Graph structural properties of non-Yutsis graphs allowing fast recognition",
        "The many facets of upper domination",
        "Finding perfect auto-partitions is NP-hard",
        "The Racah-Wigner algebra in quantum theory",
        "Deterministic single exponential time algorithms for connectivity problems parameterized by treewidth",
        "On the complexity of the maximum cut problem",
        "On interval routing schemes and treewidth",
        "On the max min vertex cover problem",
        "Feedback vertex set on graphs of low clique-width",
        "Imposing connectivity constraints in forest planning models",
        "A linear time algorithm for a variant of the MAX CUT problem in series parallel graphs",
        "Connected max cut is polynomial for graphs without K5∖esubscript𝐾5𝑒{K}_{5}\\setminus e as a minor",
        "On the (co)girth of a connected matroid",
        "Introduction To Algorithms",
        "Linear time solvable optimization problems on graphs of bounded clique-width",
        "Upper bounds to the clique width of graphs",
        "Parameterized algorithms, vol. 4",
        "Solving connectivity problems parameterized by treewidth in single exponential time",
        "A note on the approximation of a minimum-weight maximal independent set",
        "Large-or-minors in 3-connected graphs",
        "Computing the Largest Bond of a Graph",
        "On the reduction of Yutsis graphs",
        "Max-cut and max-bisection are NP-hard on unit disk graphs",
        "Theoretical improvements in algorithmic efficiency for network flow problems",
        "On some extremal problems in graph theory",
        "Parameterized Algorithms for Maximum Cut with Connectivity Constraints",
        "The largest bond in 3-connected graphs",
        "Almost optimal lower bounds for problems parameterized by clique-width",
        "On maximum leaf trees and connections to connected maximum cut problems",
        "Improving Vertex Cover as a Graph Parameter",
        "Computers and Intractability: A Guide to the Theory of NP-Completeness",
        "The planar hamiltonian circuit problem is NP-complete",
        "Algebraic Graph Theory",
        "Improved approximation algorithms for maximum cut and satisfiability problems using semidefinite programming",
        "Multi-terminal network flows",
        "Optimal price zones of electricity markets: a mixed-integer multilevel model and global solution approaches",
        "Maximum cut on line and total graphs",
        "Finding a maximum cut of a planar graph in polynomial time",
        "Approximation and intractability results for the maximum cut problem and its variants",
        "Approximation algorithms for connected maximum cut and related problems",
        "On the maximum weight minimal separator",
        "Reducibility among Combinatorial Problems, pp. 85–103",
        "Weighted upper edge cover: Complexity and approximability",
        "Optimal inapproximability results for MAX‐CUT and other 2‐variable CSPs?",
        "Parameterizing above guaranteed values: MaxSat and MaxCut",
        "Probability and Computing: Randomized Algorithms and Probabilistic Analysis",
        "Matching is as easy as matrix inversion",
        "Asymptotic enumeration methods",
        "Finding the maximal cut in a graph",
        "Matroid theory, vol. 3",
        "Improved fixed parameter tractable algorithms for two “edge” problems: MAXCUT and MAXDAG",
        "Clique-width of graphs defined by one-vertex extensions",
        "Graph minors. V. excluding a planar graph",
        "Parameterized Complexity of Multi-Node Hubs",
        "Approximating graph-constrained max-cut",
        "Graph cut based image segmentation with connectivity priors",
        "Edge dominating sets in graphs",
        "Mathematical apparatus of the theory of angular momentum",
        "Maximum minimal vertex cover parameterized by vertex cover"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 59 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Computing the Largest Bond and the Maximum Connected Cut of a Graph This work is partially supported by JST CREST JPMJCR1401, and JSPS KAKENHI grant numbers JP17H01788, JP16K16010, JP17K19960, and JP19K21537, and by São Paulo Research Foundation (FAPESP) grant number 2015/11937-9, and Rio de Janeiro Research Foundation (FAPERJ) grant number E-26/203.272/2017, and by National Council for Scientific and Technological Development (CNPq-Brazil) grant numbers 308689/2017-8, 425340/2016-3, 313026/2017-3, 422829/2018-8, 303726/2017-2. The Japanese authors thank Akitoshi Kawamura and Yukiko Yamauchi for giving an opportunity to discuss in the Open Problem Seminar in Kyushu University, Japan. Preliminary versions of this paper appeared in [27] and [22]., providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
